main.headline: We set out with a mission to make all the world’s art freely accessible to anyone with an Internet connection.
To fulfill this mission, we’re building the largest public database of art for educational use…
main.credit: Édouard Manet, Luncheon on the Grass (Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe), 1863, Musée d'Orsay, Paris

main.headline: …and making it possible to find and collect art and design from galleries around the world—all in one place.
main.credit: Marco Tirelli, Axel Vervoordt Gallery, Antwerp

main.headline: Galleries shared over 8,000** shows and over 80,000 for-sale artworks on Artsy…,
…and collectors inquired on over $5.5 billion of art.
400 museums and institutions now share their exhibitions and collections on Artsy…
…building an educational database of over 230,000 artworks.
We added over 100 categories to the Art Genome Project…
…and we supported emerging curators together with the Rauschenberg Foundation.
Benefit auctions on Artsy helped raise more than $10.8 million for the arts, AIDS research, and more…
Artsy’s technology made bidding easy, whether you were in room or on the other side of the globe.
Artsy covered 37 fairs around the world—allowing collectors to browse the works before fairs opened…
…and Artsy’s mobile app guided fair visitors to their favorite works and artists.
Artsy now has partners in 82 countries…
…and the average distance between collector and seller is now 2,700 miles
We’re bringing together galleries, fairs, museums, and auctions, so that anyone can access all the world’s art.
main.credit: Richard Serra, Backdoor Pipeline, 2010. Courtesty of Gagosian Gallery

conclusion.message: Thank you everyone who made this possible.
